item.title: [Tut] Best HelloWorld Ever
item.dc:creator: @Starblaster100 Starblaster100
item.description:
@Starblaster100 wrote:

Javacisnotrecognized:

And… the “main” is the method called by default by the JVM when you use a class file. The methods work in Java is that they are defined by their name and the syntax of their arguments. Like you could have a void main(String[] args) and another void main(Object something), and the JVM would consider them seperate unrelated things. The exact kind of void the JVM is looking for is one named “main”, that is “static”, and takes one argument of the type “String[]”.

aha, so Public Static void (String[] Args) (Or whatever it was :P) is like a main loop in SCAR. Thanks for that, and thanks for clearing up the ++ for me Bobdole

Read full topic

item.title: [Tut] Best HelloWorld Ever
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:20, topic:26370”]You don’t have to write “Tester = Tester++”, you can just use Tester++.
The exact way it works is that writing “Tester++;” increases the value of Tester by 1, and also returns the value of Tester++. Like writing

int I = Tester++;

Is valid, and would result in I equalling the value Tester had after it was ++ 'ed.
On the other hand,

int I = ++Tester;

Would make the value of Tester increase by one, but I would equal the value of Tester before it was ++ 'ed.[/quote]

You got it mixed up java

Prefixing with ++ increments any other operations are done, where as suffixing with ++ increments afterwords.

int i = 0;

// The follow are identical, as there are no other operations taking place.
i++;
++i; // i == 2 after this operation

// The follow are different, however
int j = ++i;  // j == 3 after this operation, and i == 3
int k = i++; // k == 3 after this operation, but i == 4

This concept applies to all operations in java, both arithmetic and bitwise (I believe).

Read full topic

And… the “main” is the method called by default by the JVM when you use a class file. The methods work in Java is that they are defined by their name and the syntax of their arguments. Like you could have a void main(String[] args) and another void main(Object something), and the JVM would consider them seperate unrelated things. The exact kind of void the JVM is looking for is one named “main”, that is “static”, and takes one argument of the type “String[]”.

item.title: [Tut] Best HelloWorld Ever
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[quote=“Starblaster100, post:15, topic:26370”]Thanks

YAY!

[php]
public class HelloWorld {

public static void main(String[] args) {

	int Tester;

	System.out.println("Hello, World!");
	Tester = 1 + 1;
	System.out.println("Tester = " +Tester);
	Tester = ++Tester;
	System.out.println("Tester = " +Tester);
}

}[/php]

Can anyone explain to me when these statements mean?
[php]public static void main(String[] args)[/php]

I know “public” - Sets if other (Classes?) can access this procedure or not.
I know “Main” is the procedure name.
What is the rest, and the parameters? If anyone could explain in relations to SCAR that would be great

Thanks

Star[/quote]

You don’t have to write “Tester = Tester++”, you can just use Tester++.
The exact way it works is that writing “Tester++;” increases the value of Tester by 1, and also returns the value of Tester++. Like writing

int I = Tester++;

Is valid, and would result in I equalling the value Tester had after it was ++ 'ed.
On the other hand,

int I = ++Tester;

Would make the value of Tester increase by one, but I would equal the value of Tester before it was ++ 'ed.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Starblaster100 wrote:

ok, still don’t quite get static. If it isn’t static, what is it, and what are the differences? (Like i could replace Procedure with Function with SCAR - Function returns a variable.)

Thanks, understand void. I take it i can replace void with, boolean, string, int?

String[] Args is like saying Const in SCAR terms?
Like String[] MaxFightTime, Username, Password etc?

Thanks for the help guys, appreciated!

item.title: [Tut] Best HelloWorld Ever
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Static means it belong to the class instead of an instance of the object. If this were not the case, the java application could not be run by java.exe

Read full topic

item.title: [Tut] Best HelloWorld Ever
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

static means, like, if it’s changed at all, it’s changed for everything (I think, lmao)

Void means there is no return on it. No value is sent back. Like, it’s a procedure rather than a function (In scar terms)

String[] args is the shit you put in the run.bat
Like, java HelloWorld thisisonearg thisisasecondarg thisisathirdarg

Read full topic

public class HelloWorld {

	int Tester;

	Tester = 1 + 1;
	System.out.println("Tester = " +Tester);
	Tester = ++Tester;
	System.out.println("Tester = " +Tester);
}

}[/php]

Can anyone explain to me when these statements mean?
[php]public static void main(String[] args)[/php]

I know “public” - Sets if other (Classes?) can access this procedure or not.
I know “Main” is the procedure name.
What is the rest, and the parameters? If anyone could explain in relations to SCAR that would be great
